author: Craig Ray
title: Boks stay focused for Scotland game | Rugby
text:
Duane Vermeulen mixes it with Samoa’s Tim Nanai-Williams on Saturday. It was Vermeulen’s first match since neck surgery less than three months ago. Picture: REUTERS/PETER CZIBORRA Related articles Ja, boet, told you the Boks would ‘moer’ those Samoans Springbok skipper Jean de Villiers out of Rugby World Cup Fresh hope for Springboks after Samoa mauling Le Roux braces for aerial assault in crunch clash Samoa surprise Springboks with starting team In this article Companies and organisations: Springboks Topics: Rugby World Cup People: Heyneke Meyer THE Springboks’ 46-6 win over Samoa was vital for their prospects at the World Cup, but it does not mask the fact that the team still has some way to go to be considered title contenders.
The Boks need to show consistency now after bouncing back from their humiliating 34-32 loss in Brighton in week one to Japan, to secure only their second Test win of the season.
One victory does not mean all is right in the Bok camp, especially after senior players blatantly disregarded coach Heyneke Meyer’s instructions against Japan.
On Saturday, tactically captain Jean de Villiers and vice-captain Victor Matfield were on the same page as Meyer, but will the comfortable margin of the win over Samoa seduce players to overrule the coach again?
The challenge now for the Boks is to back up the Samoa performance against Scotland in Newcastle this weekend. And they will have to do it without De Villiers, who was ruled out of the tournament with a fractured jaw.
De Villiers showed glimpses of a return to form after an injury-plagued season. His absence leaves a dearth of experienced centres in the squad, which is particularly problematic from a defensive standpoint. Matfield also has a hamstring strain and might miss the Scotland Test. At least in Lood de Jager, there is more than adequate cover in the short term.
"This has done a lot for our self-confidence because the loss to Japan really hurt and it still hurts," flyhalf Handré Pollard said. Pollard played inside centre for the final 15 minutes with both Jesse Kriel and Damian de Allende injured.
"We are going to take the pain of that defeat against Japan to the next game and all the way through the entire World Cup. We have to work harder and keep improving because one win is not enough.
"As a whole squad, we know we are not where we want to be and we will have to keep improving.
"Playing in Newcastle will be like an away game because it’s so close to Scotland. But we saw against Samoa, if we stick to our South African style of play, we perform well."
No8 Duane Vermeulen, who came through the full 80 minutes against Samoa after three months out of the game following neck surgery, was not carried away with the result against Samoa.
"This is just our first step forward at this World Cup and something we can build from here," Vermeulen said. "But we have to put it behind us and focus on Scotland. We have improved, but we still have a lot of work to do. We won’t be celebrating too long.
"Against Japan, we showed some weak points and we worked hard on that and defensively, we did a lot better. Now we have to keep improving," the No 8 said.
